central_thesis: This book compiles a diverse range of 17th-century magical and medical practices from the perspective of a London cunning-man, Arthur Gauntlet. It showcases the operative mechanics of various charms, conjurations, and prayers, drawing upon established grimoire traditions and personal experience to provide practical solutions for issues ranging from healing and protection to wealth attraction and control over spirits.

structure_content.summary: Provides historical context for 17th-century London magic, detailing the role of cunning-folk, the legal landscape (Witchcraft Act of 1604), and the intermingling of medicine and magic. It establishes the manuscript's approximate dating (1620s/early 1630s) and introduces Arthur Gauntlet and his speculatrix, Sarah Skelhorn, through contemporary accounts by William Lilly. The chapter also traces the manuscript's provenance, identifying key owners like Elias Ashmole, Lord Somers, Lord Jekyll, and Sir Hans Sloane, highlighting its transmission through significant occult figures.

structure_content.chapter_title: Material copied into and from Sloane MS 3851
structure_content.summary: A table outlining the specific folios of the manuscript and identifying the source texts from which material was copied (e.g., Arbatel, Heptameron, Agrippa's Fourth Book of Occult Philosophy, Discoverie of Witchcraft, Key of Solomon) and, in some cases, later works that copied from the Sloane MS. It notes the dates of these sources, emphasizing Gauntlet's use of foreign editions or earlier manuscripts different from later English publications.

Explains the editorial conventions used in reproducing the manuscript, including formatting for original colors, expansions of contractions, conversions of Roman numerals, and replacement of symbols. It also addresses the challenges of transcribing the faded and stained original text, noting instances of corrupted Latin ('voces magicae').

structure_content.chapter_title: Sloane MS 3851 â€“ the Manuscript (Contents Page)
structure_content.summary: Lists the main sections of the original manuscript, such as 'Instructions of Ptolomy', 'Instructions of Cyprian', 'Searles Prayer', 'Magick of Arbatel', 'Signum Pentaculum Salomonis', 'Spells Experiments Conjurations etc', '4th Book of the hidden Philosophy writ by Corn. Agrippa', 'Wm. Bacon's Roman Secret & other spells', 'The Book of the 7 Images', 'Charms for diverse diseases', 'To have Conversure with Spirits', and 'Experiments'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Instructions of Ptolomie / Instructions of Cyprian
structure_content.summary: Details foundational requirements for magical operations, emphasizing ritual purity (clean hands, feet, bathing, clean clothes, abstinence from carnal lusts) and mental fortitude (firm faith, secrecy, strong mind, clean conscience, knowledge of planetary hours). These sections underscore the ethical and practical prerequisites for successful magical work.

Presents a condensed version of the Arbatel, focusing on its theoretical framework through 49 Aphorisms. These aphorisms cover principles of wisdom, the nature of spirits (Olympical Spirits, Pygmies), the importance of divine names and characters, and ethical guidelines for the magician (righteousness, constancy, avoiding idolatry). It also includes seals and characters for the seven Olympic Spirits (Aratron, Bethor, Phaleg, Och, Hagith, Ophiel, Phul) and their attributions.

A compilation of practical magical workings, including various conjurations for angels and spirits (e.g., for sight and conference, for specific requests), binding rituals for both good and evil spirits, and instructions for making demands for things like finding lost items or healing sickness. It details the use of a Crystal Stone for scrying and includes specific prayers and divine names for invoking entities like Gabriel and Michael.

structure_content.chapter_title: 4th Book of the hidden Philosophy writ by Corn. Agrippa
structure_content.summary: Explores Agrippa's theories on spirit names and characters, explaining how they are derived from celestial figures and the succession of signs. It provides tables of characters for both good and evil spirits, alongside forms and figures of familiar spirits (e.g., of Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sol, Venus, Mercury, Moon), detailing their appearances and attributes. The section also discusses the consecration of various magical tools and places.

structure_content.chapter_title: Wm. Bacon's Roman Secret & other spells
structure_content.summary: Contains conjurations attributed to William Bacon, notably 'The Roman Secret touching the Spirit called Sathan', which describes a method for Sathan to appear in a basin to reveal past, present, and future events. It includes specific instructions for setting up the ritual, involving candles, a sword inscribed with divine names, and the drawing of a circle.

Presents instructions for creating seven magical images, each attributed to a specific day of the week and planetary influence, for various magical purposes. It describes the materials (gold, silver, wax), inscriptions (divine names, angel names, planetary signs), and specific conjurations for angels like Michael, Gabriel, Samael, Anael, and Cassiel, tailored to the planetary day and desired outcome (e.g., making tongues still, causing love, creating discord).

A collection of medical and healing charms, including remedies for a thorn prick, madness, falling sickness (epilepsy), bleeding, toothache, and ague. These charms often involve writing specific words or Psalms on objects, applying herbs, or reciting prayers, sometimes with a belief in their transmission through historical figures like Lady Ayscough.

structure_content.chapter_title: To have Conversure with Spirits / Experiments of the Dead
structure_content.summary: Provides methods for communicating with spirits, including specific instructions for calling the spirit of a dead person. The 'Experiments of the Dead' details a grave ritual involving prayers, a crystal stone, and a hazel wand, aiming for the spirit to appear as a child and answer questions. It also describes a conjuration for a spirit called Bealphares for treasure and other purposes.

structure_content.chapter_title: Experiments of the Herb vervain / Experiments of the Herb Elitrapa / Experiments of the Herb yarrow / Experiments for Love
structure_content.summary: A collection of folk magic experiments utilizing specific herbs (vervain, Elitrapa, yarrow) and other ingredients (apples, blood, animal parts) for various purposes, notably love, invisibility, protection against enemies, healing, and locating hidden gold. These practical instructions often involve writing words, consuming items, or carrying charms, with detailed timing and preparation.

Contains charms and rituals designed to ensure success in games or gambling. These involve specific stones (Solsequium), images made of gold, and animal parts (swallow's feather, bat's blood) inscribed with names and words, to be carried or used in specific ways before playing.

key_concepts.definition: A 17th-century local magical practitioner in London who provided services such as healing, recovering lost goods, protection from witches, love charms, and locating hidden treasure.
A female seer or scryer who used a crystal or glass for spirit communication and receiving visions, as exemplified by Sarah Skelhorn.
A book of magical instructions, recipes, and rituals, often containing conjurations, charms, and prayers, compiled for practical use.

A foundational grimoire providing a theoretical framework for magic through Aphorisms, outlining the nature of spirits (especially Olympic Spirits), ethical considerations for the magician, and methods for interaction with divine and elemental entities.
A concise, instructive principle or statement of truth, used in the Arbatel section to convey the theoretical and philosophical underpinnings of magic.

Holy signs or seals, often intricate designs combining divine names, sigils, and astrological symbols, used for protection, spirit control, and achieving specific magical effects. They are designed to preserve from evil and allure good spirits.

A consecrated and delineated physical space, typically drawn on the ground or parchment with specific dimensions (e.g., 14 feet wide for the Master, 4 feet over for the spirit), inscribed with divine names and symbols. It serves as a protective barrier for the practitioner and a locus for spirit manifestation.
A magical tool, emphasized in Gauntlet's work, used in consecrations and charms, suggesting a practical and portable alternative to more elaborate implements like swords.
Sacred names of God (e.g., Adonay, Eloy, Sabaoth, Tetragrammaton) and angels, invoked in conjurations to compel spirits and access divine power for magical operations.

Seven planetary spirits (Aratron, Bethor, Phaleg, Och, Hagith, Ophiel, Phul) described in the Arbatel, each governing specific days, hours, and realms, with distinct characters, powers, and legions of subservient spirits.

Symbolic representations or sigils of spirits (good or evil), planets, or divine names, used in inscriptions on various magical tools, parchments, and objects to facilitate their invocation or binding.

The burning of specific aromatic substances (e.g., red saunders, aloes, pepper, mastic, saffron, brimstone) as offerings or purifications during magical rituals, often associated with planetary days and spirits.

practical_system.description: The practical system of 'The Grimoire of Arthur Gauntlet' is a comprehensive collection of operative magic, synthesizing elements from various grimoire traditions and likely Arthur Gauntlet's personal practices. It emphasizes rigorous preparation, precise timing, and the use of consecrated tools and specific invocations to achieve a wide array of magical effects, from spiritual communication and healing to material gain and protection. The system relies heavily on direct interaction with spirits (angels, planetary spirits, fairies, demons, and the dead) through scrying and conjuration.
tools: Crystal Stone or Glass: Primary scrying medium for spirit communication.
Wand: A primary magical tool for consecrations and directing energy.
Pentacles and Seals: Inscribed with divine names, sigils, and astrological symbols for protection and spirit control.
Parchment: Virgin parchment for writing names, characters, and images for charms and conjurations.
Blood: Used from animals (bat, red cock, pigeon) or human (middle finger) for inscriptions.
Herbs: Vervain, Elitrapa (Wild Cucumber), Yarrow, Valerian, Betony, Laurel, various sweet herbs, saffron, pepper, mastic, aloes, brimstone for charms, fumigations, and ointments.
Metals: Lead, silver, gold for images and inscriptions.
Clay: For inscribing names of suspected thieves.
Knife: White-handled knife for drawing circles and inscriptions.
Candles: For illumination and setting a sacred space.
Basin or Urinal (Bottle): For containing water used in scrying or healing rituals.
Altar: For placing tools and performing invocations.
Stones: Solsequium, Lapis Lazuli, Agate Stone for specific magical properties.
Ring: For certain protective or influence-based charms.
Sword: Used for drawing circles and in conjurations for binding spirits.
Hazel Rods: For certain spirit workings.
Images: Figurines or drawings of spirits, target individuals, or symbolic representations for various magical purposes.
rituals: Ritual Purity and Preparation: Involves cleansing the body (washing hands/feet, bathing in laurel/herbs), wearing clean clothes, and maintaining sexual abstinence for specific durations (e.g., 3 or 9 days) before an operation.

Angel Conjuration (General): Requires blessing oneself, reciting prayers (e.g., Psalms, Lord's Prayer, Creed), and using specific invocations with divine names (e.g., Adonay, Eloy, Sabaoth) to call upon angels for sight, conference, and specific requests. Often involves a Crystal Stone and a child seer.

Olympic Spirit Conjuration (Arbatel): Tailored to specific planetary days and hours, using the unique characters and seals of the seven Olympic Spirits (Aratron, Bethor, Phaleg, Och, Hagith, Ophiel, Phul) to compel them to grant knowledge, wealth, or other boons. Includes specific fumigations for each day.

Fairy Conjuration (Oberion): Utilizes engraved images of Oberion and his counsellors (Scorax, Carmelion, Severion, Cabereon) on lead or silver, combined with divine name invocations, to compel the King of the Fairies to appear and fulfill desires, often in the likeness of a 'Boy of 7 years'.

Demon Conjuration (Sathan, Lucifer, Dentalion, Bealphares): Involves writing names on parchment, using blood, and powerful invocations with divine names to bind and compel demons for love, finding stolen goods, or other purposes, often with threats of damnation if disobedient.

Spirit of the Dead Conjuration: Performed at a fresh grave, involves drawing a circle, kneeling, and using specific invocations to call the spirit of the deceased to answer questions, often appearing as a child.

Healing Charms (Toothache, Fever, Ague, Bleeding, Madness): Employs various methods including writing specific words or Psalms on herbs, bread, or objects, applying them to the patient, or consuming them, often with accompanying prayers and divine names.

Love Charms: Involves inscribing names or magical words on apples, herbs (vervain), or animal parts with blood, which are then given to the desired person to eat, carried by the practitioner, or placed in specific locations, often timed with planetary influences (e.g., Moon increasing, hour of Venus).
Protection Charms: Writing divine names and symbols on parchment to be carried on the person for general protection against enemies, sickness, and misfortune.

Theft/Lost Goods Charms: Using clay with suspected names, or specific demon bishops (Teltrion, Spiron, Boytheon, Mayrion) conjurations, to reveal thieves or cause them to return stolen items, sometimes by inflicting torment or dreadful visions.
Invisibility Experiments: Involves carrying a bean from a roasted black cat's heart or using water of fennel with specific invocations.
Gaming Charms: Utilizes specific stones (Solsequium), engraved images of gold, or animal feathers (swallow's wing, bat's blood) to be carried or used in specific ways for success in gambling.
Consecration of Tools/Places: Involves blessings with holy water, fumigations, and specific prayers to imbue magical tools (wand, pentacles, circle) and the operative space with divine virtue.

relevant_quotes.text: This Book in the handwriting of one Mr Arthur Gauntlet, who professed Physick, and lived about Gray's Inn Lane.

I was very familiar with one Sarah Skelhorn, who had been Speculatrix unto one Arthur Gauntlet about Gray's Inn Lane, a very lewd fellow, professing physick. This Sarah had a perfect sight, and indeed the best eyes for that purpose I ever yet did see.

The magic circles found at fo.l14v-115 have some very interesting features which are not seen in other grimoires, and which would seem to be the result of experience being applied. Thus we see the circles having a larger and more spacious diameter of fourteen foot, not the standard nine foot found in many grimoires drawing on the Heptameron.
The only magical tool emphasised is the wand. There is a consecration of a wand given, as well as charms which require the use of a wand.

He appeareth like a king with a crown on his head, he is under the government of the @and ?, he teacheth a man knowledge in physick, and he showeth the nature of stones herbs and trees and of all metal. He is a great and mighty king, and he is king of the fairies...
A 17th century London Cunning-man's book of charms, conjurations and prayers

critical_analysis.relevance: This grimoire offers invaluable insight into the practical magical traditions of 17th-century London, particularly the role of the 'cunning-man' and the synthesis of high ceremonial magic with folk practices. Its unique preservation of material from diverse grimoires (Heptameron, Arbatel, Agrippa, Scot) and the inclusion of Arthur Gauntlet's own experiential adaptations (e.g., larger magic circles) make it a crucial primary source for understanding the development and transmission of Western Esotericism during a pivotal period. The detailed provenance further illuminates the intellectual networks of occultists, physicians, and scholars of the era.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic researchers and historians of Western Esotericism, occultism, and early modern European popular culture; practitioners of grimoire magic and ceremonial magic interested in historical methods and primary source material; and individuals studying the history of medicine, folk magic, and witchcraft beliefs in England.
